anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 738 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated December 16, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 105 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree, dated December 16, 1960 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 105 of 1957.

facts.text: Suit filed on August 10, 1956 by Shri Lal Saheb Bhargavendra Singh (deceased, represented by legal representatives) against Union of India, State of Vindhya Pradesh (merged in Madhya Pradesh), and Collector of Satna.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit filed on August 10, 1956 by Shri Lal Saheb Bhargavendra Singh, number deceased and represented by his legal representatives, against the Union of India, the State of Vindhya Pradesh, number merged in the State of Madhya Pradesh, and the Collector of Satna, for a declaration that he was entitled to receive an allowance of Rs. 650 per month from the Union of India.

facts.text: Plaintiff claimed declaration of entitlement to Rs. 650 per month allowance from Union of India.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a suit filed on August 10, 1956 by Shri Lal Saheb Bhargavendra Singh, number deceased and represented by his legal representatives, against the Union of India, the State of Vindhya Pradesh, number merged in the State of Madhya Pradesh, and the Collector of Satna, for a declaration that he was entitled to receive an allowance of Rs. 650 per month from the Union of India.

facts.text: Shri Lal Saheb was the brother of the Ruler of the former Indian State of Nagod.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Lal Saheb was the brother of the Ruler of the former Indian State of Nagod and he companytended that the Ruler had by a law passed on March 7, 1948 provided for an allowance for him at the rate of Rs. 650 per month and that law was binding on the defendants who had by an executive order illegally altered the amount of the maintenance.

facts.text: Ruler of Nagod passed an order on March 7, 1948 providing allowance of Rs. 650 per month to Shri Lal Saheb.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Lal Saheb was the brother of the Ruler of the former Indian State of Nagod and he companytended that the Ruler had by a law passed on March 7, 1948 provided for an allowance for him at the rate of Rs. 650 per month and that law was binding on the defendants who had by an executive order illegally altered the amount of the maintenance.

facts.text: Suit dismissed by trial Court.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the trial Court but was decreed by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on appeal by the plaintiff.

facts.text: Suit decreed by High Court of Madhya Pradesh on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was dismissed by the trial Court but was decreed by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on appeal by the plaintiff. Hence this appeal.

facts.text: On March 18, 1948, Ruler of Nagod along with Rulers of neighbouring states formed United State of Vindhya Pradesh, component states merged and lost sovereign status.

anchor.surface_text: Certain events that took place after March 7, 1948 when the allowance was fixed have number to be stated. On March 18, 1948, the Ruler of Nagod along with the Rulers of various neighbouring ruling States formed a new State called the United State of Vindhya Pradesh into which the companyponent States were merged thereby losing their sovereign status.

facts.text: United State of Vindhya Pradesh merged in India by agreement, Government of India took over administration on January 1, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the United State merged in India by an agreement and pursuant thereto the Government of India took over its administration on January 1, 1950.

facts.text: Territories of United State became Indian province of Vindhya Pradesh, United State ceased to exist.

anchor.surface_text: Its territories then became the Indian province of Vindhya Pradesh The United State ceased to exist.

facts.text: On promulgation of Constitution on January 26, 1950, Province of Vindhya Pradesh became Part C State.

anchor.surface_text: On the promulgation of the Constitution on January 26, 1950 the Province of Vindhya Pradesh became a Part C State of Independent India

facts.text: From November 1, 1956, Vindhya Pradesh merged with State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: and later from November 1, 1956 it was merged with the State of Madhya Pradesh.

facts.text: By agreement constituting United State, all laws in force in constituent States continued in force.

anchor.surface_text: By the agreement companystituting the United State all laws in force in the companystituent States were companytinued in force

facts.text: Laws of United State continued in force by statutory order when it merged in India.

anchor.surface_text: and likewise, the laws of the United State were by a statutory order companytinued in force when it merged in India.

facts.text: Article 372 of Constitution continued in force all laws in territories of India before commencement.

anchor.surface_text: Article 372 of the Constitution companytinued in force all laws which were in force in the territories of India immediately before the companymencement of the Constitution.

facts.text: Neither United State nor succeeding Indian Province or States made any law concerning allowance to Shri Lal Saheb.

anchor.surface_text: Neither the United State number the Indian Province or States which successively administered the territories of the State of Nagod had made any law companycerning any allowance to be paid to Shri Lal Saheb.

facts.text: Rajpramukh of United State and President of India passed executive orders fixing Shri Lal Saheb's allowance at lower amounts than Rs. 650.

anchor.surface_text: The Rajpramukh  the head  of the United State and the President of India had passed orders from time to time fixing his allowance at amounts lower than that at which it had been fixed by the Ruler of Nagod on March 7, 1948.

facts.text: These orders were executive orders, not laws.

anchor.surface_text: These were, however, executive orders and number laws.

facts.text: All events described are not in controversy.

anchor.surface_text: All this is number in companytroversy.

facts.text: President reduced allowance to Rs. 530 per month by order of September 24, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, companypetent to the President  1   1962 Supp. 1 S. C. R. 405 acting in his executive capacity to reduce it to a sum of Rs. 530 per month as he did by his order of September 24, 1951 which was challenged in the, suit.

facts.text: Order of Ruler of Nagod dated March 7, 1948 addressed to Chief Minister.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Ruler of Nagod which is said to be a law, is addressed to the Chief Minister of the State and directs him to do certain things.

facts.text: Order recited Shri Lal Saheb's deplorable financial position and Ruler's duty to provide for him.

anchor.surface_text: It starts by reciting that Shri Lal Sahebs financial position was deplorable and the Ruler felt it to be his duty to see that Shri Lal Saheb did number experience difficulties in his advancing years

facts.text: Order granted Kothi (house) to Shri Lal Saheb for generation to generation, Rs. 650 per month allowance, tonga and horse, Rs. 5,000 for agriculture and debts.

anchor.surface_text: Hence, I order that  the Kothi   in which he is at present residing  be given to Shri Lal Saheb for generation to generation and an allowance of Rs 650  Rupees six hundred and fifty , per month be granted, in addition to the same a tonga and a horse be given, the expenses for which shall be borne by himself and Rs. 5,000  Rupees five thousand , be granted to him so that he may be able to make improvements in agriculture and satisfy his debts  partly .

facts.text: Copy of order sent to Shri Lal Saheb and relevant departments.

anchor.surface_text: Then we find that a companyy of the order was sent under the, direction of the Revenue Minister to Shri Lal Saheb and various parts of it, to the different departments of the Nagod Administration respectively companycerned with them

facts.text: Revenue Minister directed Accounts Officer to report on provision for Rs. 5,000.

anchor.surface_text: Further, it appears that the Revenue Minister directed the Accounts Officer to make a report regarding the provision to be made for the sum of Rs. 5,000 mentioned in the order.

facts.text: Ruler of Nagod gave evidence that he passed the order under legislative powers.

anchor.surface_text: We should fore companycluding state that the Ruler of Nagod who made the order of March 7, 1948 himself gave evidence stating that lie had passed the order under his legislative powers.

facts.text: High Court held the order of March 7, 1948 had force of law.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, therefore, held that the allowance had been fixed by law and decreed the suit.

issues.text: The only question in this appeal is whether the order of the Ruler of Nagod of March 7, 1948 was a law

anchor.surface_text: The only question in this appeal is whether the order of the --Ruler of Nagod of March 7, 1948 was a law.

arguments.claim: Ruler of Nagod passed a law on March 7, 1948 providing an allowance of Rs. 650 per month which is binding on defendants who illegally altered it by executive order

anchor.surface_text: Shri Lal Saheb was the brother of the Ruler of the former Indian State of Nagod and he contended that the Ruler had by a law passed on March 7, 1948 provided for an allowance for him at the rate of Rs. 650 per month and that law was binding on the defendants who had by an executive order illegally altered the amount of the maintenance.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s is number in companytroversy. The only question in this appeal is whether the order of the --Ruler of Nagod of M

arguments.court_reasoning: Order not a law as it is a direction to officer, administrative communication, grant out of bounty per modern jurisprudence and multi-factor test

arguments.claim: Order of March 7, 1948 had force of law as line between legislative and executive functions of Rulers not clear-cut and futile to contend it was executive

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed that this Court had in various cases ending with the case of Madhaorao Phalka v. State of Madhya Pradesh held that the line between the legislative, executive and judicial functions of absolute Rulers like the Ruler of Nagod was not at all clear-cut and an attempt to place an order of such a Ruler in one class or the other was of no practical importance.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: was futile to companytend that the order of March 7, 1948 was an executive act of the Ruler and had number the force of law. The High Court, therefor

arguments.court_reasoning: Misconception of prior decisions; every order not law; must apply multi-factor test independently

arguments.claim: To determine if Ruler's order is legislative act, consider nature of order, scope and effect, context, promulgation method, and allied matters

anchor.surface_text: The true legal position is that whenever a dispute arises as to whether an Order passed by an absolute monarch represents a legislative act all relevant factors must be considered before the question is answered the nature of the order, the scope and effect of its provisions, its general setting and context, the method adopted by the Ruler in promulgating legislative as distinguished from executive orders, these and other allied matters will have to be examined before the character of the order is judicially determined.

arguments.claim: Instruments like merger agreements, statutory orders, Art. 372 use 'law' in sense of modern jurisprudence, so Ruler's order must qualify as such

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, not correct to say as the High Court did, that this Court has held that every order of the Ruler is a law made by him. The question whether it is so or not, has to be determined in each case independently. We then proceed to discuss whether the order of the Ruler of Nagod was law. The question arises because, as earlier stated, the covenant constituting the United State, certain statutory orders made from time to time and lastly Art. 372 of the Constitution said that the existing laws would be so continued.

arguments.claim: Order addressed to Chief Minister directing him to do certain things; direction to officer cannot be law per modern jurisprudence

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Ruler of Nagod which is said to be a law, is addressed to the Chief Minister of the State and directs him to do certain things. It starts by reciting that Shri Lal Sahebs financial position was deplorable and the Ruler felt it to be his duty to see that Shri Lal Saheb did not experience difficulties in his advancing years and as no permanent arrangement had been made for him till then, the ruler was making the order.

arguments.claim: Copy of order sent to Shri Lal Saheb and departments concerned, indicating administrative treatment not as law

anchor.surface_text: Then we find that a copy of the order was sent under the direction of the Revenue Minister to Shri Lal Saheb and various parts of it, to the different departments of the Nagod Administration respectively concerned with them, obviously with the object that they might be carried out. This would indicate that even the Administration was not treating it as law for it would be difficult to imagine different parts of a law being communicated to different branches of the Administration.

arguments.claim: Revenue Minister directed Accounts Officer to report on provision for Rs. 5,000; not how a law is implemented

anchor.surface_text: Further, it appears that the Revenue Minister directed the Accounts Officer to make a report regarding the provision to be made for the sum of Rs. 5,000 mentioned in the order. This is not how a law is carried out.

arguments.claim: Order is a grant of kothi, tonga, horse, Rs. 5,000; grant is not a law

anchor.surface_text: The order was also an instrument granting something to Shri Lal Saheb. Under it a kothi (house), a tonga (carriage) and horse and Rs. 5,000 in a lump were to be made available to Shri Lal Saheb. In regard to these the order was only a grant it gave him these things. A grant is, of course, not a law. That would follow from the decisions of this Court in Narsing Pratap Deos case and State of Gujarat v. Vora Fiddali.

arguments.claim: Monthly allowance part also a grant; future payments do not make it law

anchor.surface_text: Now if the rest of the order was a grant, it would be strange that one part of it only, namely, the part providing for the monthly allowance only, was a law. Obviously this was also intended to be a grant the fact that the order provided for future payments cannot make it a law.

arguments.claim: Recitals show Ruler discharging moral obligation out of bounty; laws not made for such reasons

anchor.surface_text: Again, the recitals in the order put it beyond doubt that the Ruler was only discharging what he considered his moral obligation. After referring to Shri Lal Sahebs deplorable financial position, he said, I take it to be my duty to, see that Shri Lal should not experience difficulties in his old days. The Ruler was, therefore, providing for something out of his bounty and in discharge of his moral obligation. A law is never made for these reasons.

arguments.claim: Payment from State Exchequer does not turn directive or grant into law

anchor.surface_text: It was said that the money was to be paid out of the State Exchequer. There is nothing to show, however, that it was so or that in Nagod the private funds of the Ruler were separate from the State Exchequer. But assume that the payment was to come from the State Exchequer. That cannot turn a directive or a grant into a law.

arguments.claim: Promod Chandra case distinguishable as there grants under pre-existing rules/laws

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn to the decision of this Court in Promod Chandra Dev v. The State of Orissa where a grant of an allowance was held to be law. That case is clearly distinguishable. There the nature and condition of allowances to be granted to persons entitled to them from the State had been laid down in Order 31 of the Rules, Regulations and Privileges of Khanjadars and Khorposhdars.

arguments.claim: Ruler passed order under legislative powers

anchor.surface_text: We should also state that the Ruler of Nagod who made the order of March 7, 1948 himself gave evidence stating that he had passed the order under his legislative powers.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of Khanjadars and Khorposhdars. It was held that those rules, regulations of Talcher etc.  1937  were the laws of the State and that the grants made

arguments.court_reasoning: Statement does not conclude; internal evidence shows not legislative

arguments.claim: If order were law, could only be altered by duly made law by succeeding states

anchor.surface_text: Each succeeding State could, of course, alter the laws which were so continued in force in spite of the change of sovereignty, by a law duly made by it. ... The contention that the order of March 7, 1948 being a law could be set aside only by a law duly passed by the succeeding States, emphasises this view.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: by the Ruler in accordance with those laws became the absolute property of the grantee. What bad happened there was that earlier lands had been grant

arguments.court_reasoning: Premise accepted but order not law so executive reduction valid

holdings.text: The true legal position is that whenever a dispute arises as to whether an Order passed by an absolute monarch represents a legislative act all relevant factors must be considered before the question is answered the nature of the order, the scope and effect of its provisions, its general setting and context, the method adopted by the Ruler in promulgating legislative as distinguished from executive orders, these and other allied matters will have to be examined before the character of the order is judicially determined.

anchor.surface_text: The true legal position is that whenever a dispute arises as to whether an Orders passed by an absolute monarch represents a legislative  1  1961 1 S. C. R. 957. A. I. R. 1964 S. C. 1793,1798. act all relevant factors must be companysidered before the question is answered the nature of the order, the scope and effect of its provisions, its general setting and companytext, the method adopted by the Ruler in promulgating legislative as distinguished from executive orders, these and other allied matters win have to be examined before the character of the order is judicially determined.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from prior decisions of this Court including Narsing Pratap Deo; rejects view that every Ruler order is law; requires case-by-case determination using specified factors.

holdings.text: The word 'law' in merger agreements, statutory orders, and Article 372 is used in the sense acceptable to modern jurisprudence.

anchor.surface_text: It is, therefore, not correct to say as the High Court did, that this Court has held that every order of the Ruler is a law made by him. The question whether it is so or not, has to be determined in each case independently. We then proceed to discuss whether the order of the Ruler of Nagod was law. The question arises because, as earlier stated, the covenant constituting the United State, certain statutory orders made from time to time and lastly Art. 372 of the Constitution said that the existing laws would be so continued.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Instruments deal with sovereign rights based on modern legal notions; succeeding states' laws fully conform to modern jurisprudence; emphasized by petitioner's contention requiring law to override.

holdings.text: The order of the Ruler of Nagod of March 7, 1948 was not a law.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied multi-factor test: addressed as direction to Chief Minister; implemented administratively by sending copies to departments and seeking reports; constituted grant of property and bounty motivated by moral duty; internal evidence overrides Ruler's testimony; distinguished Promod Chandra.

holdings.text: The order of the Ruler of Nagod of March 7, 1948 was not continued in force after the State of Nagod lost its sovereignty.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from not being a law; no continuation under merger agreement, statutory orders, or Article 372.

holdings.text: The order of the Ruler of Nagod of March 7, 1948 was an executive act of the Ruler providing for certain allowance to Shri Lal Saheb.

anchor.surface_text: The order was an executive act of the Ruler providing for certain allowance to Shri Lal Saheb.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Characterized by tests applied above distinguishing from legislative act.

holdings.text: It was competent to the President acting in his executive capacity to reduce the allowance to Rs. 530 per month by order dated September 24, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: It was, therefore, competent to the President acting in his executive capacity to reduce it to a sum of Rs. 530 per month as he did by his order of September 24, 1951 which was challenged in the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior order being executive, successor executive authority can modify by executive order.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the appeal must be allowed and we direct accordingly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding order as law; suit declaration rejected.

edges.explanation: a4 argues Ruler's order qualifies as law based on usage in statutory orders etc., addressing i1
The argument (a5) that a direction to an officer cannot be law per modern jurisprudence supports the holding (h3) that the order was not a law.
Argument (a5) applying modern jurisprudence to conclude the order is not law addresses the issue (i1) of whether the order was a law.

The definition of law in modern jurisprudence (c10), stating law must conform to jurisprudential notions and directions to officers are not law, grounds the argument (a5) that the order to the Chief Minister cannot be law.
The modern jurisprudential definition excluding directions to officers as law (c10) supports the holding (h3) that the specific order was not a law.
The concept of law's definition in modern jurisprudence (c10) addresses the issue (i1) by providing the criteria to determine if the order qualifies as law.
